## Statistical thinking{background-color='#e6effb'}

:::: columns
::: {.column width="60%"}
* Use your brain

* Avoid statistical recipes

* Avoid bright-line thinking

* Stress test your models; "If at first you succeed, try, try and try again." Andrew Leigh

* Be prepared to be wrong (DOI: [10.1038/s41562-021-01203-8](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/34711978/))
:::

## What is statistics?

-   Statistics uses data to inform decision making
-   Data literacy is a key skill for most researchers

::: incremental
-   Bland and Altman: "Bad statistics makes bad research, bad research
    may lead to bad medicine, and bad medicine may cost lives."
-   David Spiegelhalter: "Why do people find probability so unintuitive
    and difficult? ...
-   ... Well after years of careful research I have finally concluded
    that it's because probability actually is unintuitive and
    difficult."
:::

## Current state of research

<p style="font-size:66%">Correctable weaknesses in the design, conduct, and analysis of biomedical and public health research studies can produce misleading results and waste valuable resources. Small effects can be difficult to distinguish from bias introduced by study design and analyses. An absence of detailed written protocols and poor documentation of research is common. Information obtained might not be useful or important, and statistical precision or power is often too low or used in a misleading way. Insufficient consideration might be given to both previous and continuing studies. Arbitrary choice of analyses and an overemphasis on random extremes might affect the reported findings. Several problems relate to the research workforce, including failure to involve experienced statisticians and methodologists, failure to train clinical researchers and laboratory scientists in research methods and design, and the involvement of stakeholders with conflicts of interest. Inadequate emphasis is placed on recording of research decisions and on reproducibility of research. Finally, reward systems incentivise quantity more than quality, and novelty more than reliability.</p>

DOI: [10.1016/S0140-6736(13)62227-8](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/24411645/)

## Declaration of Helsinki

* Updated in 2024

<p style="font-size:80%">"Medical research involving human participants must have a scientifically sound and rigorous design and execution that are likely to produce reliable, valid, and valuable knowledge and avoid research waste. The research must conform to generally accepted scientific principles, be based on a thorough knowledge of the scientific literature, other relevant sources of information, and adequate laboratory and, as appropriate, animal experimentation."</p>

## Dilemma game


:::: columns
::: {.column width="50%"}
<p style="font-size:80%">The paper I worked on very hard is nearly finished. Next week is the deadline of the special edition of a prestigious journal. My student assistant then shows me an article that looks very similar to mine. A model that I present as new in my article has apparently already been published. Luckily, it was published in  a lesser-known journal. What do I do?</p>
:::
  
::: {.column width="50%"}
<p style="font-size:70%; color:#8DF863">A. I pretend to have never read the article and do not mention it in my own article. I hope the reviewers of the journal don‚Äôt know the other article either. </p>

<p style="font-size:70%; color:#61F527">B. At points in my article that overlap with the other article I refer to the other article, thereby risking my paper being rejected because of a lack of substantive contribution. </p>

<p style="font-size:70%; color:#4DF40B">C. I refer to the other article to a very limited extent so my article appears to be original. </p>

<p style="font-size:70%; color:#3FC809">D. I drop the paper and focus on another project.</p>
:::
::::
  
  


::::aside
From [Erasmus university](https://www.eur.nl/en/about-university/policy-and-regulations/integrity/research-integrity/dilemma-game)

## Normal dogma{background-color='white'}

```{r}
library(ggplot2)
library(dplyr)
TeachingDemos::char2seed('wigan')
mean1 = 120
mean2 = 150
sd = 13
random1 = data.frame(distance = rnorm(n=350, mean = mean1, sd=sd), group = 1)
random2 = data.frame(distance = rnorm(n=350, mean = mean2, sd=sd), group = 2)
random = bind_rows(random1, random2)
# normality test
sw = shapiro.test(random$distance)
label = paste('Shapiro-Wilk p-value = ', format.pval(sw$p.value, eps=0.001, digits=2), sep='')
test = data.frame(x = (mean1+mean2)/2, y = 5, label = label)
# plot
hplot = ggplot(data = random, aes(x = distance))+
  geom_histogram()+
  geom_text(data = test, aes(x=x, y=y, label=label), size = 6, alpha=0.8, col='white')+
  theme_bw()+
  xlab('Systolic blood pressure (mmHg)')+
  ylab('Count')+
  theme(panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
        text = element_text(size=16))
hplot
```

## Normal dogma{background-color='white' visibility="uncounted"}

```{r}
# arrow and text
text = data.frame(group = 1, x = (mean1+mean2)/2, y = 51, label = 'Difference')
arrow = data.frame(group=1, x1 = mean1, x2 = mean2, y1 = 50, y2 = 50)
#
colours = c('skyblue','darkorange2')
hplot = ggplot(data = random, aes(x = distance, fill=factor(group)))+
  geom_histogram()+
  scale_fill_manual(NULL, values=colours)+
  geom_segment(data = arrow, aes(x = x1, y = y1, xend = x2, yend = y2),
               arrow = arrow(ends = 'both', length = unit(0.03, "npc")))+
  geom_text(data = text, aes(x=x, y=y, label=label))+
  theme_bw()+
  xlab('Systolic blood pressure (mmHg)')+
  ylab('Count')+
  theme(panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
        legend.position='none',
        text = element_text(size=16))
hplot
```

## Normal residuals (left-overs){background-color='white' visibility="uncounted"}

```{r residuals}
random= mutate(random,
               residual = ifelse(group == 2, distance - mean2, distance - mean1))
#
# normality test
sw = shapiro.test(random$residual)
label = paste('Shapiro-Wilk p-value = ', format.pval(sw$p.value, eps=0.001, digits=2), sep='')
test = data.frame(group=1, x = 0, y = 5, label = label)
#
hplot = ggplot(data = random, aes(x = residual, fill=factor(group)))+
  geom_histogram(alpha=0.4)+
  geom_text(data = test, aes(x=x, y=y, label=label), size=6, col='white')+
  scale_fill_manual(NULL, values=colours)+
  theme_bw()+
  xlab('Residual')+
  ylab('Count')+
  theme(panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
        legend.position='none',
        text = element_text(size=16))
hplot
```

## Biases creep in

<p style="font-size:85%">‚Ä¢ Participant says they don't feel well</p>

<p style="font-size:80%">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;- In the intervention group you tell them to come back tomorrow</p>

<p style="font-size:80%">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;- In the control group you say nothing</p>

<p style="font-size:85%">‚Ä¢ Participant knows their treatment group</p>

<p style="font-size:80%">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;- In the intervention group they may feel more positive</p>

<p style="font-size:80%">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;- In the control group they may feel like they've missed out</p>

<p style="font-size:85%">‚Ä¢ Participant says they don't feel well</p>

<p style="font-size:80%">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;- In the intervention group you tell them to come back tomorrow</p>

<p style="font-size:80%">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;- In the control group you say nothing</p>

<p style="font-size:85%">‚Ä¢ Participant knows their treatment group</p>

<p style="font-size:80%">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;- In the intervention group they may feel more positive</p>

<p style="font-size:80%">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;- In the control group they may feel like they've missed out</p>

<p style="font-size:85%">‚Ä¢ Animal studies that did not use randomisation and blinding were far more likely to have a positive result, odds ratio = 5.2 (95% CI: 2.0 to 13.5)</p>

## Many biases

**Confirmation bias**: our prior beliefs can influence every stage of scientific research ([course on this by C4R](https://www.c4r.io/units-meeting/confirmation-bias)) 

**Expectation bias**: people's expectations about the experiment can influence the results, e.g., telling a research participant, "This is going to hurt."

## Many biases{visibility='uncounted'}

**Confirmation bias**: our prior beliefs can influence every stage of scientific research ([course on this by C4R](https://www.c4r.io/units-meeting/confirmation-bias)) 

**Expectation bias**: people's expectations about the experiment can influence the results, e.g., telling a research participant, "This is going to hurt."

Long list of biases [here](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_cognitive_biases) -- we are all prone to bias, we need to actively work against biases when conducting research


## Spend time on your data

* Excel is useful, but there are many common mistakes
*	Be consistent in naming variables and categories, e.g., never: "Male", "male" and "m" in same variable
* Write dates as YYYY-MM-DD, e.g, 2018-10-16

## Spend time on your data{visibility='uncounted'}

* Excel is useful, but there are many common mistakes
*	Be consistent in naming variables and categories, e.g., never: "Male", "male" and "m" in same variable
* Write dates as YYYY-MM-DD, e.g, 2018-10-16
* Don't put multiple variables in one cell, e.g., never "Injury - morning"
* Never record information in cell colours 
* One rectangular data set per Excel sheet	
* <small>**Please please please** read and keep this paper:  Karl W. Broman & Kara H. Woo (2018) [Data Organization in Spreadsheets](https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/00031305.2017.1375989), _The American Statistician_, **72**:1, 2--10</small>

* Randomisation isn't always about intervention versus control
 
* We could randomise:
 
  + The order of questions in a questionnaire
 
  + The order of observations, e.g., is a 20 or 30 degree bed angle better for lung volume?


## Randomise everything{visibility='uncounted'}

* We could randomise:
 
  + The order of questions in a questionnaire
 
  + The order of observations, e.g., is a 20 or 30 degree bed angle better for lung volume?

## Randomisation tutorial

<p style="font-size:62%">A US state can only afford to give free health care to half its citizens so it decides to randomly allocate healthcare to half the population. A bureaucrat realises that this could be a great way to study the benefits of health care and so suggests a random allocation scheme.</p>

<p style="font-size:62%">‚Ä¢ What are the advantages and disadvantages to the following random allocations:</p>

<p style="font-size:57%">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;+ Get a full list of the population and randomly allocate everyone</p>

<p style="font-size:57%">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;+ Cover people whose birthday is odd (e.g., 17th Jan covered, 8th August not covered)</p>

<p style="font-size:57%">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;+ Cover people whose birthday is in the second half of the year (e.g., 17th Jan not covered, 8th August covered)</p>

<p style="font-size:57%">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;+ Cover people if the last digit on their social security number is odd</p>

<p style="font-size:57%">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;+ Cover everyone in the youngest half of the population</p>
  
<p style="font-size:62%">‚Ä¢ What primary and secondary outcomes would you collect? And over what time frames?</p>

<p style="font-size:62%">‚Ä¢ Routinely collected data (e.g., death) may not give a complete picture of the benefits. What other data might you collect?</p> 


## Randomisation answers

<p style="font-size:62%">The 2008 [Oregon Health Insurance Experiment](http://www.nber.org/oregon/1.home.html)</p>

<p style="font-size:62%">‚Ä¢ The RAND Health Insurance Experiment was an experimental study of health care costs, use and outcomes in the United States, which assigned people randomly to different kinds of plans and followed their behaviour, from 1974 to 1982</p>

<p style="font-size:62%">‚Ä¢ Uninsured low-income adult residents invited to put their name on a list</p>

<p style="font-size:62%">‚Ä¢ State drew 30,000 names by lottery from a list of 90,000; about 10,000 eventually ended up being enrolled in Medicaid (exclusions)</p>

<p style="font-size:62%">‚Ä¢ Selected individuals won the opportunity -- for themselves and any household member -- to apply for coverage</p>


## Randomisation answers{visibility="uncounted"}

<p style="font-size:62%">The 2008 [Oregon Health Insurance Experiment](http://www.nber.org/oregon/1.home.html)</p>

<p style="font-size:62%">‚Ä¢ The RAND Health Insurance Experiment was an experimental study of health care costs, use and outcomes in the United States, which assigned people randomly to different kinds of plans and followed their behaviour, from 1974 to 1982</p>

<p style="font-size:62%">‚Ä¢ Uninsured low-income adult residents invited to put their name on a list</p>

<p style="font-size:62%">Results:</p>

<p style="font-size:57%">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;+ Decrease in depression in first two years</p>

<p style="font-size:57%">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;+ 25% decrease in the probability of unpaid medical bills that are sent to a collection agency</p>

## <small>Coin tossing (a simple experiment)</small>{visibility="uncounted"}

:::: columns
::: {.column width="65%"}

<p style="font-size:80%">‚Ä¢ We want to know if a coin is fair</p>

<p style="font-size:80%">‚Ä¢ Simple experiment of tossing it 10 times (should be a sufficient sample size)</p>

<p style="font-size:80%">‚Ä¢ What would we expect to see if the coin was fair?</p>

<p style="font-size:80%">‚Ä¢ Null **hypothesis**:</p>
    
<p style="font-size:80%">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;- H$_0$: the coin is fair</p>
    
<p style="font-size:80%">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;- H$_1$: the coin is not fair</p>

<p style="font-size:80%">or in stats language</p>

<p style="font-size:80%">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;- H$_0$: Probability(heads) = 0.5</p>

<p style="font-size:80%">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;- H$_1$: Probability(heads) $\neq$ 0.5</p>

:::
  
::: {.column width="35%"}
![](figures/coin_toss.jpg)
:::

## Testing a new coin (running a new study)

<p style="font-size:80%">‚Ä¢ Run a new experiment with our coin of unknown fairness</p>

<p style="font-size:80%">‚Ä¢ Compare new results with the **distribution** from a fair coin</p>

<p style="font-size:80%">‚Ä¢ If we observed 10 heads we would be inclined to think it wasn't fair</p>

## Testing a new coin (running a new study){visibility="uncounted"}

<p style="font-size:80%">‚Ä¢ Run a new experiment with our coin of unknown fairness</p>

<p style="font-size:80%">‚Ä¢ Compare new results with the **distribution** from a fair coin</p>

<p style="font-size:80%">‚Ä¢ If we observed 10 heads we would be inclined to think it wasn't fair</p>

<p style="font-size:80%">‚Ä¢ Based on our fair coin distribution this would only happen 2 in 1000 times (probability = 0.002)</p>

<p style="font-size:80%">‚Ä¢ _p_-value is the probability of observing equally extreme data _if_ the null hypothesis is true</p>

<p style="font-size:80%">‚Ä¢ _p_-value is a **surprise value**</p>

<p style="font-size:80%">‚Ä¢ If we saw such an extreme result we'd probably want to take a good look at the coin, or ask who ran the experiment (do we trust the data?)</p>

## The context of the experiment
* In ten trials of each experiment the correct guess is made every
    time
* Each experiment has the same _p_-value (0.002 from our simulations)
* Are we convinced that the music expert has a talent?
* Do we really think the drunk friend is psychic?

## The context of the experiment{visibility="uncounted"}
* In ten trials of each experiment the correct guess is made every
    time
* Each experiment has the same _p_-value (0.002 from our simulations)
* Are we convinced that the music expert has a talent?
* Do we really think the drunk friend is psychic?
* We don't treat the evidence equally for each trial
* Instead we judge the evidence based on context and our prior experience
* _p_-values must be seen in context (part of the story)


## _p_-value $<$ 0.05 $\Rightarrow$ statistical significance

<p style="font-size:80%">‚Ä¢ There's a generally accepted rule that a _p_-value $<$ 0.05 is statistically significant, whilst any _p_-value $\geq$ 0.05 is not</p>

<p style="font-size:80%">‚Ä¢ Means there's a 0.05 (1 in 20) chance of rejecting the null hypothesis when it's true</p>

## _p_-value $<$ 0.05 $\Rightarrow$ statistical significance{visibility='uncounted'}

<p style="font-size:80%">‚Ä¢ There's a generally accepted rule that a _p_-value $<$ 0.05 is statistically significant, whilst any _p_-value $\geq$ 0.05 is not</p>

<p style="font-size:80%">‚Ä¢ Means there's a 0.05 (1 in 20) chance of rejecting the null hypothesis when it's true</p>

<p style="font-size:80%">‚Ä¢ **Historical hangover** from early work by Roland Fisher in 1926:</p>

<p style="font-size:80%">"If one in twenty does not seem high enough odds, we may, if we prefer it, draw the line at one in fifty or one in a hundred. Personally,
the writer prefers to set a low standard of significance at the 5 per cent
point, and ignore entirely all results which fails to reach this level. A
scientific fact should be regarded as experimentally established only if a
properly designed experiment rarely fails to give this level of
significance."</p>


## _p_-value $<$ 0.05 $\Rightarrow$ statistical significance

<p style="font-size:80%">‚Ä¢ Means that studies with a _p_-value of 0.0499999 are "accepted", whilst those with a _p_-value of 0.0500000 are not, but</p>
<p style="font-size:75%">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;- this is only a tiny jump in evidence</p>
<p style="font-size:75%">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;- and is a jump that is not itself statistically significant! E.g., in study with an outcome of body mass index it might be the difference between one subject cutting their toenails or not!</p>

## _p_-value $<$ 0.05 $\Rightarrow$ statistical significance{visibility="uncounted"}

<p style="font-size:80%">‚Ä¢ Means that studies with a _p_-value of 0.0499999 are "accepted", whilst those with a _p_-value of 0.0500000 are not, but</p>
<p style="font-size:75%">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;- this is only a tiny jump in evidence</p>
<p style="font-size:75%">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;- and is a jump that is not itself statistically significant! E.g., in study with an outcome of body mass index it might be the difference between one subject cutting their toenails or not!</p>

<p style="font-size:80%">‚Ä¢ Lazy decision rule and should be avoided</p>

<p style="font-size:80%">‚Ä¢ A _p_-value of 0.06 is substantially different than a _p_-value of 0.99</p>

<p style="font-size:80%">‚Ä¢ Always write the _p_-value as a number, **never** write "Non significant" or "p $>$ 0.05" for a _p_-value above 0.05</p>

</small>

## The bias for "significance"

<p style="font-size:80%">‚Ä¢ RCT of a fabricated journal manuscript with two versions:</p>
<p style="font-size:75%">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;-One with statistically significant results (P = 0.003)</p>
<p style="font-size:75%">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;-One with no difference (P = 0.18)</p>

<p style="font-size:80%">‚Ä¢ Sample size of 210 peer reviewers</p>

:::: aside

## The bias for "significance"{visibility="uncounted"}

<p style="font-size:80%">‚Ä¢ RCT of a fabricated journal manuscript with two versions:</p>
<p style="font-size:75%">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;-One with statistically significant results (P = 0.003)</p>
<p style="font-size:75%">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;-One with no difference (P = 0.18)</p>

<p style="font-size:80%">‚Ä¢ Sample size of 210 peer reviewers</p>

<p style="font-size:80%">‚Ä¢ Reviewers given the positive version were more likely to:</p>
<p style="font-size:75%">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;- Recommend publication (97% vs 80%, P $<$ 0.001)</p>
<p style="font-size:75%">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;- Detect errors (0.9 vs 0.4, P $<$ 0.001)</p>
<p style="font-size:75%">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;- Award higher scores to the _identical_ methods section (8.2 vs 7.5, P = 0.005)</p>

## Practical significance

* With a big enough sample size, almost any comparison will be statistically significant

* The size of the difference matters the most



<!--- from https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s40279-025-02227-0 --->

## Practical significance{visibility='uncounted'}

* With a big enough sample size, almost any comparison will be statistically significant

* The size of the difference matters the most

* 1% improvement in blood pressure might be statistically significant but practically useless

* Pre-specify the important difference (likely need some thinking)

# Confidence intervals{background-color='#d7bde2'}

## Confidence intervals{background-color='white'}

:::: columns
::: {.column width="50%"}
* A 95% confidence interval will reach the same conclusions as a two-sided 5% _p_-value

* Picture shows confidence intervals (horizontal lines), means (black dots), and null hypothesis of no change (horizontal dotted line)
:::
  
::: {.column width="50%"}
![](figures/ci_plots.png)
:::
::::


## Confidence intervals

<p style="font-size:80%">‚Ä¢ The important number for confidence intervals is usually zero</p>

<p style="font-size:80%">‚Ä¢ E.g., "The new training schedule increased total distance by 1&nbsp;km (95% CI: --1&nbsp;km, 3&nbsp;km)"</p>

<p style="font-size:80%">‚Ä¢ So at the lowest end the new schedule actually decreased the total distance by 1&nbsp;km</p>

## Confidence intervals{visibility='uncounted'}

<p style="font-size:80%">‚Ä¢ The important number for confidence intervals is usually zero</p>

<p style="font-size:80%">‚Ä¢ E.g., "The new training schedule increased total distance by 1&nbsp;km (95% CI: --1&nbsp;km, 3&nbsp;km)"</p>

<p style="font-size:80%">‚Ä¢ So at the lowest end the new schedule actually decreased the total distance by 1&nbsp;km</p>

<p style="font-size:80%">‚Ä¢ Confidence intervals **are better** than _p_-values because they contain more information and they test the null hypothesis</p>

<p style="font-size:80%">‚Ä¢ For rate ratios or odds ratios the null hypothesis is at one, e.g., "The new training schedule increased the number of injuries by 2.0 compared with the existing schedule (95% CI: 1.2, 3.0)" --- which would mean a statistically significant increase in injuries</p>


## Ring toss{background-color='#634522'}

:::: columns
::: {.column width="50%"}
* Calculating a confidence interval is like throwing a ring toss

* A larger ring is more likely to include the target

* Rings either include or exclude the target
:::
  
::: {.column width="50%"}
![](figures/ring_toss.jpg)
:::
::::

:::: aside
Photo by [Michael Coghlan](https://www.flickr.com/photos/mikecogh/15948532925/in/photostream/) CC BY-SA 2.0
::::

## Overlapping intervals{background-color='white'}

:::: columns
::: {.column width="60%"}
* Be careful about judging statistical significance between two groups from confidence intervals
* Picture assumes equal standard errors (confidence interval widths) --- even harder to judge if this isn't true
:::
  
::: {.column width="40%"}
![](figures/overlapping_ci.png)
:::
::::

* "What causes what?" is a common question in research

## Confounders{background-color='white'}


:::: columns
::: {.column width="40%"}
* Often wrongly defined

* Must effect **both** the outcome and the intervention

* Confounder must occur before the intervention
:::
  
::: {.column width="60%"}
![](figures/confounders1.jpg)
:::
::::

<!--- from draw_confounder.R --->



## Strong predictors{background-color='white'}


:::: columns
::: {.column width="40%"}
* Strong predictors are associated with the outcome but not the exposure (or intervention)

* Useful to know, but not necessary to answer the research question

:::
  
::: {.column width="60%"}
![](figures/confounders1b.jpg)
:::
::::

<!--- from draw_confounder --->


## Over-adjusting{background-color='white'}

:::: columns
::: {.column width="40%"}
* Tempting to add all variables into the model and let the "clever" algorithm decide
* Don't add variables if there's no plausible direct link with the outcome
:::
  
::: {.column width="60%"}
![](figures/confounders2.jpg)
:::
::::


## Causal pathway{background-color='white'}

:::: columns
::: {.column width="40%"}
* Don't adjust for variables on the causal pathway
:::
  
::: {.column width="60%"}
![](figures/confounders2b.jpg)
:::
::::

## Don't use the future{background-color='white'}

:::: columns
::: {.column width="40%"}
* Don't adjust for anything that happens after the outcome
:::
  
::: {.column width="60%"}
![](figures/confounders3.jpg)
:::
::::

## <small>Outliers and influential observations</small>

::: {.incremental}
* If all your results rely on one person/observation, then your results are likely not generalisable. This must be acknowledged in your write-up.

* "29 of 100 papers published in Science, Nature and PNAS [...] stated significances (or their absence) are based on the presence of a single influential data point." DOI: [10.1101/2024.10.30.621016v1](https://www.biorxiv.org/content/10.1101/2024.10.30.621016v1.abstract)

:::

## Technical stuff{background-color='#291b0d'}

:::: columns
::: {.column width="50%"}
* Use the following statistics to look for outliers and influential observations:
  - Residuals (should always check)
  - Cook's distance
  - DFBETA

## Avoid long<br>surveys

![](figures/journal.pone.0258123.s002-2.png){.absolute top="20" right="20" width='600'}

## Question wording

* How do your rate your appointment?
  + Extremely happy
  + Happy
  + Unhappy

* How difficult was it to follow the treatment schedule?
  + Difficult
  + Neither easy nor difficult
  + Easy

## <small>Papers I cite a lot in my statistical reviews</small>

* Don't categorise continuous data, DOI: [10.1097/00001648-199507000-00025]()

* Don't worry about the normal assumption, DOI: [10.1146/annurev.publhealth.23.100901.140546]()

* Be very careful with matching, DOI: [10.1007/s10654-017-0325-0](https://doi.org/10.1007/s10654-017-0325-0)

* Time-dependence, DOI: [10.1016/j.jclinepi.2012.04.008]()

* Guideance for decimal places, DOI: [10.1136/archdischild-2014-307149](https://adc.bmj.com/content/100/7/608)

* Confidence intervals, DOI: [10.1002/sim.3471](https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/sim.3471)
